content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

```julia
# Define the DataFrame with car data
df_cars = DataFrame(
    manufacturer = repeat(["audi", "toyota", "ford", "audi"], 4),
    model = repeat(["a4", "a4 quattro", "camry", "f-150"], 4),
    price = [10000, 11000, 12000, 13000, 14000, 15000, 16000, 17000, 18000, 19000]
)

# Function to filter down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”
function audi_filter(df)
    # Filter down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”
    audi_df = @filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df)

    # Create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows
    audi_df[!, :audi_a4_type] = true

    # Return the resulting DataFrame
    return audi_df
end

# Test the function
println(audi_filter(df_cars))
```
